questions.question_text: A project manager is overseeing the construction of a new building. There are likely existing underground water, gas, and electrical lines. Which of the following is an example of mitigation?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is the correct answer

Selected Answer: D
A. Trust the contractor to do the job well because the company has been in business for a long time. (Sounds Like Risk Acceptance )
B. Tell the contractor that the company is responsible for any damage done to underground lines. (Sounds like Risk transference)
C. Immediately fix any broken lines that are hit during construction. (If something is already broken, it is not mitigated)
D. Ensure the contractor has the appropriate utility maps. (I think is right)

Avoidance is a common form of mitigation used by the CCC. Staff should continue to emphasize mitigation by avoidance, since it is the best way to prevent direct adverse impacts to a wetland. Minimizing, rectifying, or reducing project impacts are forms of mitigation that diminish the severity of project related impacts.

Sorry Treymb6, that is absolutely incorrect. 

When working on a project you do things to prevent damage from happening. You don't damage stuff and worry about fixing it later.
D sounds more like avoidance. Think it should be C.

questions.question_text:
A Scrum team is completing a sprint; however, some tasks will need to carry over to the next sprint.
Which of the following should the Scrum master do to improve the team's velocity in the next sprint?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
What went well (keep doing these things)
What could be improved (went OK, but could be better)
What went badly (don't do these things again)
Focus for next period/sprint/month/quarter (One or two things to focus on)

Selected Answer: C
C. sprint retrospective

Selected Answer: C
The sprint retrospective is a recurring meeting held at the end of a sprint used to discuss what went well during the previous sprint cycle and what can be improved for the next sprint. The Agile sprint retrospective is an essential part of the Scrum framework for developing, delivering, and managing complex projects.
The Sprint Retrospective is an opportunity for the Scrum Team to inspect itself and create a plan for improvements to be enacted during the next Sprint.
POE - I think Answer is B. The understanding of the risk with a detailed explanation of how the project intends to (mitigate or) address the potential for occurrence.

comments.content: Sure, understanding the risk will help in the future with risk mitigation but that process itself isn't mitigating anything. The only answer here that is an actual mitigation action would be transferring, which would be A.
The question is not asking for a mitigation technique, but for the explanation of risk mitigation.

discussion.content:
Risk mitigation
Attempts to reduce the probability or impact of a potential risk event to
an acceptable level. Mitigation may involve implementing a new course of
action in an effort to reduce the problem or changing the current
conditions so that the probability of the risk occurring is reduced.
Sometimes, when reducing the probability is not possible, the focus must
be on reducing the consequences of the risk event.

Selected Answer: A
My reasoning why A is the correct answer, is because B is more like Risk Acceptance than Risk Mitigation.

Risk mitigation is a risk strategy for negative risks whereby the project team reduces
the probability that the risk will occur or lessens the projected impact of the risk.
Pearson, 2018

choices.A: The transfer of the risk to another entity or project inside or outside the organization, along with associated costs.
choices.D: The weighting or prioritization of the risk against all other identified risks within this project or others associated with it.
choices.C: The quantification of the risk in terms of how much the risk could potentially cost the project or parent organization.
choices.B: The understanding of the risk with a detailed explanation of how the project intends to address the potential for occurrence.
